title-group.article-title: Visual Comparison of Datasets Using Mixture Decompositions

abstract.p: This article describes how a mixture of two densities, f<sub>0</sub> and f<sub>1</sub>, may be decomposed into a different mixture consisting of three densities. These new densities, f<sub>+</sub>, f<sub>-</sub>, and f<sub>=</sub>, summarize differences between f<sub>0</sub> and f<sub>1</sub>: f<sub>+</sub> is high in areas of excess of f<sub>1</sub> compared to f<sub>0</sub>;f<sub>-</sub> represents deficiency of f<sub>1</sub> compared to f<sub>0</sub> in the same way; f<sub>=</sub> represents commonality between f<sub>1</sub> and f<sub>0</sub>. The supports of f<sub>+</sub> and f<sub>-</sub> are disjoint. This decomposition of the mixture of f<sub>0</sub> and f<sub>1</sub> is similar to the set-theoretic decomposition of the union of two sets A and B into the disjoint sets A\B, B\A, and Aâˆ© B. Sample points from f<sub>0</sub> and f<sub>1</sub> can be assigned to one of these three densities, allowing the differences between f<sub>0</sub> and f<sub>1</sub> to be visualized in a single plot, a visual hypothesis test of whether f<sub>0</sub> is equal to f<sub>1</sub>. We describe two similar such decompositions and contrast their behavior under the null hypothesis f<sub>0</sub>=f<sub>1</sub>, giving some insight into how such plots may be interpreted. We present two examples of uses of these methods: visualization of departures from independence, and of a two-class classification problem. Other potential applications are discussed.
